meta.content:
COVID-19 FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS (FAQ’s)
MARCH 26, 2020 UPDATES:
11:00 a.m. - Addition of Meal Locations
Muskogee Public Schools will continue to provide meals to those 18 and under at the original four school site and four offsite bus stops. Beginning Monday, March 30, 2020 MPS will add an additional location at Whittier Elementary.
This is a curbside “Grab and Go”...

div.em: Current conditions as of 22 Apr 09:53 am CDT

div.div: Showers and possibly a thunderstorm before 1pm, then showers and thunderstorms after 1pm. Some of the storms could produce heavy rainfall. High near 70. Southeast wind 15 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 35 mph. Chance of precipitation is 80%. New rainfall amounts between 1 and 2 inches possible.

Showers and thunderstorms likely, mainly before 1am. Mostly cloudy, with a low around 56. South wind 10 to 15 mph becoming northwest after midnight. Winds could gust as high as 20 mph. Chance of precipitation is 70%. New rainfall amounts between a half and three quarters of an inch possible.
Cloudy through mid morning, then gradual clearing, with a high near 76. Northwest wind 5 to 15 mph.

div.a: Weather forecast provided by weather.gov.

p.input: Website Navigation As Staff Page Only

div.p: HTML Editor:
div.label: HTML Editor:

div.div: Your session will expire in 0 minutes.

div.p: Working...
March 16, 2020

span.span: Muskogee Public Schools will continue to provide meals to those 18 and under at the original four school site and four offsite bus stops. Beginning Monday, March 30, 2020 MPS will add an additional location at Whittier Elementary.

This is a curbside “Grab and Go” meal service only. A MPS employee will hand your child their meal while everyone remains in their vehicle or for those who walk to a location we ask that children return home to eat their meal.

The school district will provide curbside service at these sites from 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. for breakfast and from 11:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. for lunch. Students must be present to receive a meal and only one meal per student will be provided.
We will provide “Grab and Go” meals only. Since we are only providing curbside service, a staff member will be available to hand your child their meal while you are still in your car.

Furthermore, MPS will run buses to additional locations for meal pick up by students. These meals will also be “Grab and Go” as well. Breakfast buses will arrive at 7:30 a.m. and lunch buses will arrive at 11:30 a.m.

div.h4: Video update from Superintendent Dr. Jarod Mendenhall

span.span: Beginning Monday, April sixth students will begin receiving instruction remotely. We will have more details on instruction and class assignments beginning next week.
It will be imperative that all students Kindergarten through 12th grade have their Chromebook and T-Mobile Hotspots because this will be how instruction is provided to students.

Our records show that 321 students do not have their devices. We have set up a drive-up location at the New Tech building at Alice Robertson so students and parents can pick these items up.
The technology team will be available on Thursday, March 26th and Friday, March 27th from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. and then again on Saturday, March 28th from 9 a.m. to Noon. Again, it is important that everyone have these devices so that we can provide instruction remotely to everyone.

If you have questions regarding Chromebooks, T-Mobile Hotspots or other technology-related issues please feel free to call 918-684-3700 ext. 4357 OR contact the technology department by email at helpdesk@roughers.net

div.p: Video update from Superintendent Dr. Jarod Mendenhall

p.strong: SHOULD WE CONSIDER MARCH 23RD - APRIL 3RD VIRTUAL SCHOOL DAYS?

div.p: No, these days will not be considered Virtual School Days. However, MPS teachers are fully committed to ensuring that our students stay engaged in their learning during this time.

p.strong: SHOULD YOUR CHILD COMPLETE THE ASSIGNMENTS THAT WERE PROVIDED BY THEIR TEACHER?

div.p: We are encouraging our students to stay instructionally engaged in their learning while out of school. This commitment to learning will decrease the possibility of the “Spring Break Instructional Slide”. MPS has provided assignments and various links for you to work on with your child while at home.
OSDE Website: Testing Portal – Online Practice Tests (3rd - 8th Grades)
College Board SAT Practice Tests via Khan Academy (11th Grade only)
Study Island: K-12 and is aligned to state standards
Imagine Learning: ALL 6th Grade Literacy/ELL students through K - 8th grade
Alpha Plus: 6th Grade Math/7th & 8th Grade Reading/Math
Courseware Online Classes (Students already enrolled in classes for this semester)
EdOptions Online Classes (Students already enrolled in classes for this semester)

br.strong: CAN MY 6TH-12TH GRADE STUDENT ACCESS ASSIGNMENTS FROM ANOTHER DEVICE?

div.p:
Yes, students can login from another device, the student will have to login using their firstname.IDnumber@roughers.net.
Students can login using:
Google Classroom: https://classroom.google.com/h
Echo: https://nta-mpsi20.echo-ntn.org/login;url=/home

p.strong: WHAT IS MUSKOGEE PUBLIC SCHOOLS DOING TO UNDERSTAND COVID-19?
p.br: The health and safety of our students and staff are the top priority at Muskogee Public Schools. District administration is working closely with state and local health officials to stay abreast of all current information regarding the threat of Coronavirus (COVID-19). Although there are no known cases in Muskogee County, we are receiving status updates by our local health department.

There is currently no vaccine to prevent Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. More specifically, COVID -19 can spread among people that are in close contact (within 6 feet) of one another or through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

p.strong: HOW CAN I PROTECT MYSELF AND MY FAMILY FROM GETTING THIS VIRUS?
p.br: There are basic steps recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. They are as follows:

div.p: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick; put distance between yourself and other people (6 feet or more).
Cover coughs and sneezes with tissue and immediately throw away the tissue. If you don’t have a tissue, cover your mouth with the inside of your elbow.
Stay home if you are sick.

p.strong: WILL I BE NOTIFIED IF THERE IS A CASE OF COVID-19 IN MY CHILD’S SCHOOL?
p.br:
Yes, Muskogee Public Schools will notify parents as soon as we are officially notified of any confirmed case of COVID-19 in a student or campus staff member through our automated notification system.
IS THE SCHOOL DISTRICT CLEANING THE BUILDINGS AND BUSES FOR COVID-19?
Yes, Muskogee Public Schools began deep cleaning and disinfecting all school sites and school buses on Friday, March 13, 2020. This was the purpose for cancelling school the day before spring break. All door knobs, lockers and flat tabletop services have been disinfected and are ready for students to return to school.

div.p: MPS has Clorox Total 360 machines that utilize the proper chemicals to disinfect larger areas such as weight rooms, locker rooms, labs, gymnasiums and fine arts spaces. The chemicals for disinfecting all spaces were specified by the Center for Disease Control.

p.strong: WHEN MPS CLOSES SCHOOL UNTIL APRIL 6th, DO WE HAVE TO MAKE THE TIME UP?
p.br: This decision will ultimately be made by the Oklahoma State Department of Education (OSDE). The state leadership will determine the time to be made up and how that will occur. At this time, there has not been any decisions made regarding the extension of the school year.

p.strong: WHEN SCHOOL IS CLOSED, WILL WE CONTINUE TO HAVE ATHLETICS AND FINE ARTS ACTIVITIES?
p.br: No, if MPS is closed due to the potential spread of COVID-19, all activities in athletics and fine arts will be cancelled during this time period. All practices, rehearsals and contests will be cancelled as well. The purpose of a full closure (quarantine) is to stop the spread of infection through social distancing.

p.strong: WILL STUDENTS CONTINUE TO RECEIVE INSTRUCTION DURING A SCHOOL THE CLOSURE?
p.br: Yes, MPS has provided instruction for all students K-12. Premade Homework Packets were sent home with elementary students and assignments have been loaded in Google Classroom for secondary students. The following links have been provided for further instructional support and enrichment for all grades.

div.p: OSDE Website: Testing Portal – Online Practice Tests (3rd - 8th Grades)
College Board SAT Practice Tests via Khan Academy (11th Grade only)
Study Island: K-12 and is aligned to state standards
Imagine Learning: ALL 6th Grade Literacy/ELL students through K - 8th grade
Alpha Plus: 6th Grade Math/7th & 8th Grade Reading/Math
Courseware Online Classes (Students already enrolled in classes for this semester)
EdOptions Online Classes (Students already enrolled in classes for this semester)

Every student was sent home with their Chromebook computer and T-Mobile hotspot. However, parents can still pick up any materials they may not have recieved at their child’s school on Tuesday, March 18, 2020. All school facilities will be closed as of Wednesday, March 19, 2020.
Our Technology Help Desk will be available to assist parents and students with computer issues that may arise. The number is 918-684-3700, ext. 4357.

p.strong: ARE THERE LOCATIONS FOR STUDENTS TO GET FOOD?
p.br: Yes, beginning Monday, March 23, 2020 meals will be provided to those 18 and under at four (4) different school sites twice per day. The following school sites have been selected:

div.p: Muskogee High School - 3200 E. Shawnee Rd.
Cherokee Elementary - 2400 Estelle Ave.
Pershing Elementary - 301 N. 54th St.
Irving Elementary - 1100 N. J St.

The school district will provide curbside service at these sites from 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. for breakfast and from 11:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. for lunch. Students must be present to receive a meal and only one meal per student will be provided.
We will provide “Grab and Go” meals only. Since we are only providing curbside service, a staff member will be available to hand your child their meal while you are still in your car.

Furthermore, MPS will run buses to additional locations for meal pick up by students. These meals will also be “Grab and Go” as well. Breakfast buses will arrive at 7:30 a.m. and lunch buses will arrive at 11:30 a.m.
Port City Acres Apartments - 2103 N. 36th St.
Riverside Mobile Home Park - 4400 N. Gibson St.
Whispering Pines Apartments - 2061 Carroll St.
Green Country Village - 1518 South 5th Street

br.strong: DOES THE SCHOOL DISTRICT NEED VOLUNTEERS TO HELP DELIVER OR SERVE FOOD?
br.br: No, MPS is grateful for the many requests from our community to assist and volunteer. Given that the CDC is recommending that everyone practice social distancing to help prevent the spread of infection, we will be utilizing our current certified food handlers to cover this service.

p.strong: WILL SUPPORT EMPLOYEES BE PAID DURING THE SCHOOL CLOSURE.
p.br: It is our intention to pay support staff their April checks. Many support staff are considered critical path employees and will be working on-site or remotely from home. As we move further into the month of April, we will have more guidance from state and federal governments regarding school closures.

div.p:
Support employees are encouraged to be proactive and stay in contact with their supervisors for all additional information regarding work expectations.
WHAT IF I TRAVELED OVER SPRING BREAK?
If you have traveled over the break, we would ask that you fill out a brief questionnaire regarding your trip. This will help us connect you with health information/recommendations regarding travel to/from those locations.
Here is a Link to that survey: MPS SPRING TRAVEL SURVEY
Those in our MPS Family who have traveled by air or on a cruise ship, the CDC has recommended that you voluntarily quarantine you and your family members for a period of 14 days.

p.strong: INFORMATION SEEMS TO CHANGE SO QUICKLY, HOW CAN I BEST STAY INFORMED?

div.p: District Superintendent, Dr. Jarod Mendenhall will provide video updates.
Follow MPS on our social media platforms: Facebook and Twitter.
Check our website for the latest additions.
Add Oklahoma State Department of Health (OKSH) and The Center for Disease Control (CDC) to your favorites on your computer or phone.

br.strong: Video of the Special Board of Education Meeting on Monday, March 16, 2020 at 5 p.m.
